newsitem.title: USA: Saks to buy Barneys, bring it out of Chapter 11.
newsitem.headline: Saks to buy Barneys, bring it out of Chapter 11.

text.p: Upscale retailer Saks Holdings Inc. said Tuesday it plans to buy Barney's Inc., taking the luxury clothing store group out of bankruptcy with a cash and stock bid valued at $290 million.
The Saks plan has the approval of Tokyo conglomerate Isetan Co., which holds leases on three of Barney's flagship stores.
Saks said it and Isetan will submit their joint plan to a New York bankruptcy court for approval.
Barney's filed for bankruptcy in January 1996 and the retailer, home to exclusive fashions by Armani and other designers, has been involved in acrimonious legal wranglings with Isetan ever since.

Barney's, which grew from humble beginning as a bargain shop for men's and boys' clothing, has grown in recent years into a high-priced fashion trend-setter under the management of the original Barney's grandsons, Gene and Robert Pressman.
In a joint statement, Saks and Isetan said, "We believe the Saks-Isetan Joint Plan offers a global settlement to, and is the most viable resolution for, all parties in the Barney's bankruptcy.
"The combination of Saks and Isetan represents the strongest possible pairing of retailing and real estate expertise," according to the statement, released in New York.
Saks, owner of Saks Fifth Avenue stores, has had its eye on three of Barney's larger properties -- its stores in New York, Chicago and Beverley Hills.

"The acquisition of Barney's is consistent with Saks' long-term objective of enhancing its presence in the domestic and international luxury goods markets. We expect this strategic investment will be accretive to Saks shareholders," Saks said.
Under terms of the plan, unsecured creditors would receive about 20 cents on the dollar.
Saks said the investment in Barney's would add to its earnings but it did not provide figures.
Isetan said it agreed to the Saks plan despite having to accept rents "that are substantially below current market rates and the existing lease rates."
Isetan also said it will report a significant loss on its emergency loans to Barney's affiliated companies, which totalled nearly $200 million.

Separately, Saks estimated that its profits for the first quarter ending May 3 will be a lower than an expected 20 cents per share. In its fiscal fourth quarter, which includes the crucial holiday season, Saks earned $46.7 million, or 73 cents a share.

It said it based the projection on sales trends in March and April and expects to report sales of about $520 million for the quarter, lower than the $465 million posted for the same quarter itn its fiscal 1996.
Saks has 40 department stores, eight resort stores and three stand-alone stores led by its landmark flagship on New York's Fifth Avenue.
Isetan has seven full-scale department stores in the Tokyo area, including its flagship store in Shinjuku and subsidiary stores in Niigata and Shizuoka.
